channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: Sarah Berry
item.description: Meditation apps can teach us a skill that takes us well beyond life in lockdown. We reviewed six of the most popular on the market.
item.title: We tried six meditation apps. This is what we thought

item.description: Now with more gray than dark brown in his stubble, the 41-year-old Spaniard sets off for his 10th Ryder Cup at Whistling Straits to extend a remarkable run.
item.title: ‘Sergio loves the Ryder Cup’: All you need to know about golf’s most intense show

item.dc:creator: Samantha Hutchinson
item.description: It’s a case of will-they, won’t-they for Sydney’s golf clubs after a swag of Victorian golf clubs mandate jabs at courses
item.title: Sydney golfers in limbo on ‘no jab, no play’

item.dc:creator: Nick Bonyhady
item.description: Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce said international travel was getting closer as vaccination rates rise, but the extra money is a sign the industry will need help for longer than planned.
item.title: $183m in government funding to extend aviation support until March

item.dc:creator: Daniel Cherny
item.description: Proud of what his former club and teammates have achieved, Liam Jurrah admits Melbourne’s grand final berth leaves feelings of regret for what might have been.
item.title: ‘I regret it’: Jurrah’s mixed feelings ahead of Dees’ grand final

item.dc:creator: John Silvester
item.description: After Saturday’s violence and similar clashes at a demonstration on August 21, Victoria’s police chief has flagged the use of specialised riot officers at anti-lockdown rallies.
item.title: Riot police set for front line at future COVID protests

item.dc:creator: Royce Millar
item.description: Some of Victoria’s most marginalised citizens are caught up in a dispute as rival disability accommodation and support businesses fight for the right to access their funding packages under the NDIS.
item.title: Ugly turf war as service providers tussle over NDIS clients with disabilities

item.dc:creator: Phil Lutton
item.description: Penrith get the finals shot at Melbourne they so badly wanted but after two weeks of play-offs, it’s clear the Storm are a cut above those chasing their crown.
item.title: As the NRL race narrows, who can beat the Melbourne Storm?

item.dc:creator: Nick Miller
item.description: Brett Sheehy, who steps down this month as artistic director, wants the government to pass a law so theatre staff and audiences must be vaccinated.
item.title: Departing MTC director calls for mandatory theatre jabs

item.dc:creator: Michael Evans
item.description: An eight-year investigation into major drug importations climaxed with the extradition of two men from Dubai last week. But investigators raised questions about organised crime infiltrating authorities.
item.title: Sparky and Gangster: inside the rise and fall of a major drug syndicate

item.dc:creator: Zoe Samios
item.description: A four-way battle is looming for the broadcast rights to the English Premier League, which could fetch up to $240 million.
item.title: Blind auction for English Premier League rights could re-shape Aussie streaming landscape

item.dc:creator: Shane Wright
item.description: New research shows up to 70 per cent of households in suburban electorates are under mortgage financial stress as high house prices eat into the weekly budget.
item.title: Mortgage stress soars as RBA says tax system pushes up house prices

item.dc:creator: Emma Dawson
item.description: A shallow understanding of identity politics among many on the Left is a significant threat to progressive politics.
item.title: Left’s identity politics crisis a progressive problem

item.dc:creator: Danielle Cave
item.description: The real potential of AUKUS lies in how the new grouping can be leveraged in the long term to help Australia deal with the profound technological disruption about to sweep the world.
item.title: Australia well placed to turbocharge its strategic tech capability

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: Thousands of laptops have been sent to homes in Sydney’s hotspots as students face home schooling hurdles.
item.title: Demand for loan laptops another signal of a city divided by COVID

item.dc:creator: Julie Power
item.description: The number of people living with dementia - the biggest killer of women in Australia - will double by 2058, putting pressure on budgets and carers.
item.title: ‘It doesn’t mean I’m stupid’: Dementia rates set to double

item.dc:creator: Matt O'Sullivan
item.description: The plans for an area next to the new football stadium clear the way for a permanent end to the parking of vehicles on fields at Moore Park during events.
item.title: ‘Village precinct’ at Moore Park signals end to on-grass parking

item.dc:creator: Charlotte Grieve
item.description: The Maritime Union of Australia is being investigated by the industry watchdog after a whistleblower complaint raised concerns about improper selling of union cars.
item.title: Maritime Union probed over selling union cars to friends, family

item.dc:creator: Shane Wright
item.description: Australia was planning to spend $90 billion on French submarines. Now the budget faces at least a massive hit from nuclear-powered vessels.
item.title: Subs set to sail past $100 billion as defence call on budget grows

item.dc:creator: Charlotte Grieve
item.description: The banking royal commission exonerated the industry super sector leading to a boom in new members. But has this bred a complacency that serves to benefit unions and boards?
item.title: Performance test sparks scrutiny of super fund spending, union deals

item.description: Deprived of their intimate, candlelit venues, cabaret stars are learning the tricks of the online broadcasting trade.
item.title: Cabaret stars turn to gamers and influencers for streaming tips

item.dc:creator: Penny Flanagan
item.description: Are you a homo impatientus? Does standing in a queue – any queue – feel like torture? Get ready for the post-COVID world.
item.title: Lining up for the new normal? Have patience

item.dc:creator: Bevan Shields
item.description: For all the grand titles given to her, the German Chancellor leaves with a mixed legacy.
item.title: ‘She has been a trailblazer’: Angela Merkel, the Queen of Europe, bows out of politics

item.dc:creator: Timna Jacks
item.description: V/Line is in the throes of a disaster scenario. The regional rail system has been largely shut down for 10 days, with about 300 drivers isolating over several days, and disruptions are expected for weeks.
item.title: How the V/Line outbreak unfolded and what it means for the rail system

item.dc:creator: Anne Hyland
item.description: A small group of powerful men, and increasingly women, dominate the boards of Australia’s biggest companies. And some fear the group is too small.
item.title: Board games: Is a cosy directors’ club a risk to corporate Australia?

item.dc:creator: Amelia McGuire
item.description: The online gaming industry is valued at more than US$250 billion. And young Aussie Riad Chikhani is among a group that has made money from the market.
item.title: The esports publisher trying to ‘flip the media narrative on its head’

item.description: A volcano has erupted on La Palma in the Spanish Canary Islands, sending jets of lava and a plume of smoke and ash into the air.
item.title: La Palma volcano erupts in the Canary Islands, forcing evacuations

item.description: Ronaldo and Jesse Lingard goals saw Manchester United home in a dramatic game against West Ham United.
item.title: Manchester United edge out West Ham, Brighton and Chelsea secure wins

item.description: Sydneysiders will be aware that they will have nuclear-powered submarines in the harbour in the distant future.
item.title: If Morrison can deceive the French, why not us?

item.description: Trivia buffs: test your knowledge with today’s interactive superquiz and target.
item.title: Target Time and Superquiz, Monday, September 20

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The NSW government has sought to increase the amount of water permitted to be extracted from the Murray-Darling Basin, emails reveal.
item.title: NSW sought to beat Basin Plan water limits

item.dc:creator: Harry Hollinsworth
item.description: Mrs Barbara Mackay, wife of missing Griffith businessman Donald Mackay, was yesterday named Mother of the Year.
item.title: In the Herald: September 20, 1977

item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duke
item.description: The work from home revolution has many benefits. But there are also some underappreciated economic consequences we need to consider.
item.title: The economic consequences of working from home that no one is talking about

item.description: The nation was stunned when Prime minister Bob Hawke wept at a press conference while discussing his daughter’s fight with drug addiction.
item.title: From the Archives, 1984: Tearful PM vows to pursue crime

item.description: Amid the background of government inaction on emissions, climate litigation is on the rise.
item.title: As Australia’s climate policy disappoints, hope is found in court

item.description: Illustrations by the artist from The Age.
item.title: The latest illustrations from artist Matt Golding

item.description: A look at the follies, foibles and joys of the human race through the eyes of cartoonist Michael Leunig. Buy prints from Michael Leunig at https://www.thestore.com.au/category/artists/michael-leunig. Join us on Facebook at the Michael Leunig Appreciation Page.
item.title: The latest illustrations from artist Michael Leunig

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, September 20, 2021

item.dc:creator: Roy Ward
item.description: Follow along for all the action from the fashions to the final winner on our 2021 Brownlow Medal live blog.
item.title: As it happened: Wines goes big with record-equalling 36-vote Brownlow win

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, September 19, 2021

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, September 18, 2021

item.dc:creator: Shane Wright
item.description: The government is putting another $150 million towards hydrogen industry hubs as it burnishes its environment credentials ahead of a UN conference.
item.title: Government sinks another $150 million into hydrogen industry

item.dc:creator: Daniel Cherny
item.description: Port Adelaide star Ollie Wines equalled the Brownlow Medal votes record as he charged home to secure the 2021 prize in the final round of the season after a thrilling count on Sunday night.
item.title: Wines equals Martin’s record to claim Port’s first Brownlow

item.dc:creator: Shane Wright
item.description: Scott Morrison says France should have known Australia may have ditched its $90 billion sub deal, while France has accused Australia of treachery.
item.title: ‘Deep and grave concerns’: French should have seen sub decision coming, PM says

item.dc:creator: Damien Woolnough
item.description: AFL’s annual best and fairest awards benefited from a reboot with greater national input. Cue less same-same sexy, and more understated elegance.
item.title: An elevated Brownlow red carpet takes an exciting turn

item.description: Some discipline required for the tin eared.
item.title: Two fingered salutes to the whistling police

item.description: It's a Brownlow red carpet divided across cities but the common theme is glamour
item.title: Brownlow 2021: All the looks from the red carpet

item.dc:creator: Sumeyya Ilanbey
item.description: Both states are charting the path to COVID-normal, but each state has differed on what freedoms it would reward its fully vaccinated residents from that first milestone of 70 per cent second dose vaccine coverage.
item.title: Victoria v New South Wales: How does the road map differ

item.dc:creator: Noel Towell
item.description: Retailers want details of how the road map’s vaccine mandates can be enforced, while publicans are ‘gutted’ by how long it will take to reopen.
item.title: ‘Going to be very difficult’: Business disappointed at slow road ahead

item.description: An Australian man and his Thai wife sentenced to death for trafficking half a tonne of crystal methylamphetamine for the Hells Angels have been acquitted after four years in a Bangkok jail.
item.title: Australian on Thai death row for smuggling half a tonne of crystal meth released
